docs.title: Imaginary data analysis application
docs.text:
Here is a brief overview of the main documentation sections:

  • Introduction – Provides a description of EasyPeasy, including its purpose, licensing, latest release details, and contact information.
  • Installation & Setup – Guides users through system requirements, environment configuration, and the installation process.
  • User Guide – Covers core concepts, key terminology, workflow steps, and essential parameters for effective use of EasyPeasy.
  • Tutorials – Offers practical, step-by-step examples demonstrating common workflows and data analysis tasks.
  • API Reference – An auto-generated reference detailing the available functions and modules in EasyPeasy.

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: This section contains the reference detailing the functions and modules available in EasyPeasy.

docs.title: Installation & Setup
docs.text: This section is currently under development. Please check back later for updates.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
EasyPeasy is a scientific software for performing imaginary calculations based on a theoretical model and refining its parameters against experimental data.

EasyPeasy is available both as a Python library and as a cross-platform desktop application.

Here, we focus on the graphical user interface (GUI). For the Python library, please see the corresponding library resources.

EasyPeasy is developed using the EasyScience framework.

docs.title: License
docs.text: EasyPeasy application is released under the BSD 3-Clause License.

docs.title: Releases
docs.text:
The latest version of the EasyPeasy application is feature.

For a complete list of new features, bug fixes, and improvements, see the GitHub Releases page.

docs.title: Citation
docs.text:
If you use EasyPeasy application in your work, please cite the specific version you used.

All official releases of the EasyPeasy application are archived on Zenodo, each with a version-specific Digital Object Identifier (DOI).

Citation details in various styles (e.g., APA, MLA) and formats (e.g., BibTeX, JSON) are available on the Zenodo archive page.

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
We welcome contributions from the community! EasyPeasy is intended to be a community-driven, open-source project supported by a diverse group of contributors.

The project is maintained by the European Spallation Source (ESS).

To contribute, see our Contributing Guidelines on GitHub.

docs.title: Get in Touch
docs.text:
For general questions or feedback, contact us at support@easypeasy.org.

To report bugs or request features, please use the GitHub Issue Tracker (free registration required).

docs.title: Tutorials
docs.text: This section is currently under development. Please check back later for updates.

docs.title: User Guide
docs.text:
This section provides an overview of the core concepts, key parameters and workflow steps required for using EasyPeasy effectively.

Here is a brief overview of the User Guide sections:

  • Glossary – Defines common terms and labels used throughout the documentation.
  • Concept – Introduces the overall idea behind data analysis in EasyPeasy.
  • Data Format – Explains the data structures and file formats used by EasyPeasy.
  • Parameters – Describes how parameters are structured, named, and accessed within the EasyPeasy.
  • First Steps – Shows how to begin using EasyPeasy in Python or Jupyter notebooks.
  • Analysis Workflow – Breaks down the data analysis pipeline into practical, sequential steps.
